messages.text: I figured it was becoming unlikely, but I still *really* wanted to be in Lisbon this next summer.   Any thoughts as to whether or not Lisbon will still be the likely spot for the next in-person JuliaCon (whatever year that occurs in?)

really

messages.text: (I just had the horrible thought - what if just as we are coming out of this mess, we get hit by something like “novel Ebola virus” :scream: )

messages.text: No idea, really. I think the last year has cured us of the hubris of planning 18 months in advance.

messages.text:
As a favour - could you join this event page on LinkedIn - and invite a handful of few people to do likewise - one or two "Probables" would be fine
Basically the old adage is that "a Crowd brings a Crowd"
<https://www.linkedin.com/events/juliacon2021-freeandvirtual6746462348694958080/>

I know that LinkedIn is not everyone's favourite platform, but it is the best for corporate engagement. It would be easier to secure sponsorship when there is some momentum going in terms of PR

attachments.title: JuliaCon 2021 (free and virtual) | LinkedIn
attachments.text: Join us for the annual JuliaCon Conference. Workshops will be held the week before with more details coming later in 2021. #JuliaLang #JuliaCon #OpenSource

messages.text:
Can we open nominations for the community prize ASAP?
I would like to be able to nominate people as it occurs to me.
Last year I forgot to nominate until it was too late

messages.text: anyone attending R-Studio global? I'd be interested in any experience reports. They generally do a very slick job producing conferences.

elements.text: anyone attending R-Studio global? I'd be interested in any experience reports. They generally do a very slick job producing conferences.

messages.text: I wonder if there’s a way to improve the audio quality of the presentations this year? I really enjoyed the talks last year but some of them had pretty bad audio quality (like echo or background noise), especially compared to the professional recordings from earlier JuliaCons. Maybe there can be some post-processing done to remove noise, or more guidance for speakers?

elements.text: I wonder if there’s a way to improve the audio quality of the presentations this year? I really enjoyed the talks last year but some of them had pretty bad audio quality (like echo or background noise), especially compared to the professional recordings from earlier JuliaCons. Maybe there can be some post-processing done to remove noise, or more guidance for speakers?

messages.text: We could also ask speakers to edit auto-generated captions on the YouTube video, which would also help with accessibility, though ideally then the speakers would have access to the YouTube video before the event to do that ahead of time

elements.text: We could also ask speakers to edit auto-generated captions on the YouTube video, which would also help with accessibility, though ideally then the speakers would have access to the YouTube video before the event to do that ahead of time

messages.text: Pre-recorded talk with feedbacks prior to the event would be great, but it might induce a lot of additional work.

elements.text: Pre-recorded talk with feedbacks prior to the event would be great, but it might induce a lot of additional work.

messages.text:
getting rid of low level background noise should be an easy postprocess
getting rid of echo requires the speaker to know that it is happening and why

elements.text:
getting rid of low level background noise should be an easy postprocess
getting rid of echo requires the speaker to know that it is happening and why

messages.text: Having a good guide would help

elements.text: Having a good guide would help

messages.text:
Remove background noise is most likely impossible or limited. One could use products like Izotope <https://www.izotope.com/en/products/rx/features/voice-de-noise.html|https://www.izotope.com/en/products/rx/features/voice-de-noise.html>, or at least do some mastering leveling audio output levels. But that's a lot of hassle.
It would be a lot easier if ppl follow a few guidelines like recording in a quiet environment, and do not add reverb effects to recordings.

attachments.title: RX 8 Voice De-noise
attachments.text: RX’s Voice De-noise audio plug-in and module restores problematic vocal or production recordings in real time, focusing on dialogue and sung vocal treatment.

elements.text: Remove background noise is most likely impossible or limited. One could use products like Izotope
https://www.izotope.com/en/products/rx/features/voice-de-noise.html

, or at least do some mastering leveling audio output levels. But that's a lot of hassle.
It would be a lot easier if ppl follow a few guidelines like recording in a quiet environment, and do not add reverb effects to recordings.

messages.text: Linux users could use some software to remove typing/non-speaking noises during mic capture: <https://sr.ht/~arsen/alsa_rnnoise/>

elements.text: Linux users could use some software to remove typing/non-speaking noises during mic capture:

messages.text: denoising is really bad. You can always hear when it's used. Just get a good mic and fix the source

elements.text: denoising is really bad. You can always hear when it's used. Just get a good mic and fix the source

messages.text: Apparently the new rtx voice is really good, if you have an nvidia GPU. I haven't personally tried it, but heard good things online.

elements.text: Apparently the new rtx voice is really good, if you have an nvidia GPU. I haven't personally tried it, but heard good things online.

messages.text: NVIDIA Broadcast? It's fine.

elements.text: NVIDIA Broadcast? It's fine.

messages.text: I tend to use it. It's no better than tuning Izotope's tools your specific problem. Still not a catch all for a bad source.

elements.text: I tend to use it. It's no better than tuning Izotope's tools your specific problem. Still not a catch all for a bad source.

messages.text: The best I've found is manually altering frequencies in Audition, making sure to record a few minutes of background, and then running their learning process on a piece of background than snapping that down like 50%.

elements.text: The best I've found is manually altering frequencies in Audition, making sure to record a few minutes of background, and then running their learning process on a piece of background than snapping that down like 50%.

messages.text: On the Mac, I use iMovie and it has an equalizer that magically removes background noise in my videos. Honestly I don’t know how it works but it does seem to work quite well.
